text: The environmental influence over these microbial processes impacts the composition and interspecies collaboration among water and soil ecosystems, as well as within the microbial communities that inhabit the human body.
Nutrition is one factor, but niche-specific physical parameters such as temperature, pH, and osmolarity are equally important.
Most, if not all, bacteria also undergo elegant developmental processes ranging from biofilms and swarming, to sporulation or heterocyst formation.
As with metabolic adaptations, developmental programs are launched in response to environmental pressures such as starvation, desiccation, changes in temperature, and even crowding.
Elizabeth Shank and student Matthew Powers explored this question by searching for that manipulate the development of “niche-mates.
They coordinate the gathering of food with the synthesis of biomass and then adjust those processes as nutrients change in the local environment, or when they are challenged by stress.
Microbiome composition could be radically changed by such interactions.
Bacteria, as simple as they seem, perform incredibly complex and highly orchestrated processes to achieve growth.
Some hot-springs bacteria can double in as little as 10 minutes, whereas deep-sea-sediment microbes may take as long as 100 years.
In Chapter 5 we build on these concepts and explore the remarkable ways that microbes respond to environmental stress and change.
What determines these differences in growth rate?
Can one bacterial species manipulate differentiation of another?
4.16 How might Streptomyces and Actinomyces species avoid “committing suicide” when they make their antibiotics?
